<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|>
May/June 2017

1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 408]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 502, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 361, 531]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 546]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 604, 571]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 759, 586]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 655, 89]]<|/det|>
The class is investigating the resistances of two resistance wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 421, 120]]<|/det|>
The circuit used is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 134, 710, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 368, 532, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 400, 146, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
A student places a sliding contact \(\mathbf{S}\) on the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(l = 0.200 \text{m}\) from point \(\mathbf{A}\). She measures the current \(I\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V\) across the length \(l = 0.200 \text{m}\) of resistance wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 462, 653, 480]]<|/det|>
Figs. 1.2 and 1.3 show the voltmeter and ammeter readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 183, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 494, 742, 511]]<|/det|>
Write down the readings shown on the meters in Figs. 1.2 and 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 522, 455, 675]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 523, 868, 675]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 694, 331, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 694, 748, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 480, 744]]<|/det|>
\(V =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[531, 725, 892, 744]]<|/det|>
<form>I = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 742, 920, 761]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 772, 181, 790]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 771, 920, 816]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the length \(l = 0.200 \text{m}\) of resistance wire, using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 855, 920, 874]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .............................................................[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 866, 92]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the procedure using the distance \(l = 0.400 \text{m}\). Her result is shown.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 98, 781, 121]]<|/det|>
\[R = \frac{2.54\Omega}{}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 134, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 641, 152]]<|/det|>
Calculate the difference between the two values for \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 163, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<form>difference = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 195, 181, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 195, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
Suggest a relationship between the length \(l\) and the resistance \(R\) of the wire that matches the results, within the limits of experimental accuracy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 304, 176, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 303, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
Using the same method as in **(a)**, the student determines the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) of total length \(l = 0.500 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 345, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} = \frac{3.08\Omega}{}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 380, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
She then uses a short lead to connect points \(\mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). She uses the same method again to determine the combined resistance \(R_{2}\) of the resistance wires \(\mathbf{AB}\) and \(\mathbf{CD}\) connected together.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 439, 918, 462]]<|/det|>
\[R_{2} = \frac{1.50\Omega}{}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 475, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
Use the student's results to compare the resistance \(R_{1}\) of wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the resistance \(R_{2}\) of wires \(\mathbf{AB}\) and \(\mathbf{CD}\) connected together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 521, 759, 540]]<|/det|>
Tick the box next to the description that most closely matches the results.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 545, 201, 670]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 551, 303, 570]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} = R_{2}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 580, 311, 600]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} = 2R_{2}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 612, 311, 632]]<|/det|>
\[2R_{1} = R_{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 643, 655, 662]]<|/det|>
There is no simple relationship between \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 661, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 148, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
Suggest two reasons why different students, all carrying out this experiment carefully, with the same apparatus, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 738, 175, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 768, 918, 787]]<|/det|>
<form>2. ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 798, 175, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 875, 920, 894]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The class is investigating the refraction of light passing through a transparent block. A student is using optics pins to trace the paths of rays of light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 118, 485, 135]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows the student's ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 147, 823, 768]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 784, 532, 802]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 816, 146, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 816, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw and label a normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) at the centre of side \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{E}\) where the normal crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{M}\) where the normal crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 833, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 861, 178, 878]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 860, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{FE}\), to the left of the normal and at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 907, 178, 925]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 907, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
Label the positions of two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on \(\mathbf{FE}\) placed a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 925, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The student observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between his eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 574, 183]]<|/det|>
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are marked on Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets the normal **NL**. Label the point \(\mathbf{K}\) where this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 242, 144, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 242, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
• Measure and record the angle \(\alpha\) between the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the normal line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 288, 917, 306]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 673, 338]]<|/det|>
• Measure and record the length \(x\) between points \(\mathbf{M}\) and \(\mathbf{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 351, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 148, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 819, 415]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the procedure but with the line **FE** to the right of the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
He measures the angle \(\beta\) between the line joining the new positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 472, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\beta =\) .................................. $41^{\circ}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 685, 523]]<|/det|>
He measures the length \(y\) between \(\mathbf{M}\) and the new position of \(\mathbf{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 533, 918, 553]]<|/det|>
<form>y = .................................. $21 \text{mm}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 566, 918, 584]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that the results for \(\alpha\) and \(x\) should be the same as the results for \(\beta\) and \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 597, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
State whether the results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
statement ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 918, 693]]<|/det|>
justification ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 724, 920, 742]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 753, 146, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 753, 897, 772]]<|/det|>
Suggest **one** precaution that you would take with this experiment to obtain reliable results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 873, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 878, 920, 895]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 667, 91]]<|/det|>
The class is investigating images formed on a screen using a lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 364, 121]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 133, 787, 225]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 242, 532, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 273, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 475, 291]]<|/det|>
The lens has a focal length of 15.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
Suggest a suitable distance \(D\) between the illuminated object and the screen in order to form a clearly focused image on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 351, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<form>D = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 146, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
The student places the lens as shown in the diagram a distance \(u\) from the object. She then moves the screen until she obtains a clearly focused image on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 834, 446]]<|/det|>
It is difficult to decide on the exact position of the screen that gives the best image.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 834, 477]]<|/det|>
Explain how you would find the best position for the screen as reliably as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 551, 143, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 695, 570]]<|/det|>
Another student uses a different lens and obtains these readings:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 580, 833, 599]]<|/det|>
<form>u = ....................................... 15.0 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 611, 918, 630]]<|/det|>
<form>v = ....................................... 29.7 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 640, 724, 664]]<|/det|>
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 813, 693]]<|/det|>
Include the unit and give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 804, 920, 823]]<|/det|>
<form>f = ........................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Suggest one difference that you would expect to see in this experiment between the appearance of the object and the image.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 119, 920, 137]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 144, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 761, 168]]<|/det|>
Which of the following procedures, \(\mathbf{A} - \mathbf{F}\), are sensible for this experiment?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 425, 183]]<|/det|>
Circle one or more of the letters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 196, 173, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 571, 215]]<|/det|>
Carry out the experiment in a darkened room.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 228, 173, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 227, 500, 246]]<|/det|>
Close one eye when taking readings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 259, 173, 278]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 259, 324, 278]]<|/det|>
Draw thin lines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 291, 173, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 291, 495, 308]]<|/det|>
Fix the rule in position on the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 322, 173, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>E</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 322, 544, 339]]<|/det|>
Make sure the pins are at least 5 cm apart.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 352, 171, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>F</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 352, 915, 371]]<|/det|>
Repeat the experiment using different values of \(u\) and determine an average value for \(f\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 539, 90]]<|/det|> The class is investigating the principle of moments. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 411, 120]]<|/det|> Fig. 4.1 shows the apparatus used. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 133, 836, 280]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 295, 532, 313]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 144, 344]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 327, 920, 375]]<|/det|> A student places a load \(\mathbf{P}\) on the metre rule at the \(5.0\mathrm{cm}\) mark. He places the metre rule on the pivot at the \(45.0\mathrm{cm}\) mark. He places a load \(\mathbf{Q}\) on the rule and adjusts its position so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 388, 186, 406]]<|/det|> · <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 388, 784, 406]]<|/det|> He measures the distance a between the centre of load \(\mathbf{P}\) and the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 420, 176, 437]]<|/det|> · <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 420, 740, 437]]<|/det|> He measures the distance \(b\) from the centre of load \(\mathbf{Q}\) to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 451, 171, 469]]<|/det|> · <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 451, 920, 500]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure placing the load \(\mathbf{P}\) at the \(10.0 \text{cm}\) mark, the \(15.0 \text{cm}\) mark, the \(20.0 \text{cm}\) mark and at the \(25.0 \text{cm}\) mark. He keeps the pivot at the \(45.0 \text{cm}\) mark each time. The readings are recorded in Table 4.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 513, 539, 530]]<|/det|> Table 4.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 539, 621, 692]]<|/det|>
\(a/\text{cm}\)\(b/\text{cm}\)

35.036.4

25.023.9
20.017.5

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 183, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 900, 89]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(b / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(a / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 101, 744, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 483, 920, 501]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 514, 180, 532]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 892, 91]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the effect of draughts (moving air) on the rate of cooling of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 539, 122]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 475, 153]]<|/det|>
an electric fan with four speed settings

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 154, 331, 172]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 175, 266, 193]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 288, 214]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 216, 386, 234]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 236, 245, 253]]<|/det|>
stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 349, 273]]<|/det|>
clamp, boss and stand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 286, 858, 304]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of draughts on the rate of cooling of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 318, 218, 336]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 349, 655, 368]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 569, 399]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 918, 445]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 722, 476]]<|/det|>
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 488, 551, 506]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 42, 510, 60]]<|/det|>
